div1.p:
THE ZEAL AND EFFICIENCY SHOWN
BY OUR MEDICAL OFFICERS.

It is only too unlikely that persons
living in the North and having no real
knowledge of conditions in Cuba, may be led to suppose that because of the
small outbreak of yellow fever among American soldiers at Cienfuegos, the offi-
cers of our Medical Corps are to be looked upon as either incompetent or care-
less. The truth is that yellow fever has probably never been entirely eradi-
cated from the island, though kept well in check by a pursuance of the methods
established by the former intervention. Mild cases of it among the natives
have doubtless gone unrecognized, or have not been reported, but have served
to keep alive potential infection. With the coming of non-immune American
troops, the danger at once became vastly increased, for while here and there a
Cuban of the interior highlands may be liable to the disease, there has not
been but a very scant sprinkling of such in any locality, so that multiplica-
tion of cases was nowhere likely to occur.

Had the Cuban government carried out the obligation entailed upon it by
the Platt amendment and nationalized sanitation, the same methods that have
kept Havana clean, or served always to prevent the spread of the disease from
sporadic cases, would have placed the other cities of the island in a safe condi-
tion. This obvious duty was not complied with, however, and the cities out-
side the capital have been deft to their own devices, which have been those of
indifference and dilatoriness. Cienfuegos is in a disreputably unhigienic condi-
tion, and it is not at all surprising that a few American soldiers, peculiarly
exposed because on duty in the vicinity of a hospital in charge of native doctors,
who permitted some mild case of the disease to pass unreegnized or unreported,
should have contracted the infection. So far from deducing from this that the
American medical officers have been careless or incompetent, it should be in-
ferred from the fact that with the infection on the island, na American sol-
dier was attacked for nearly a year after the coming of the troops, that the med-
ical officers have been wonderfully watchful and efficient. With detachments
of non-immune soldiers scattered all over the island, and foci of yellow fever
infection at several points, the officers must have exercised the greatest care
and skill in selecting camps and quarters and keeping these and their occupants
entirely free from infection, and it is safe to say that had there been a national
sanitation law, so that the military supervisors of sanitation would have en-
joyed a free hand in the cities of the island, the present small outbreak of the
fever in Cienfuegos would have been avoided. But Major Kean and his able and
zealous lieutenants have been hampered at every step by the indifference and the
jealousy of the municipal doctors, who have resented their supervision and direc-
tion, and who have been protected by political influence. It is notorious that
many of these doctors owe their places, not to zeal or fitness, but to political
influence, which in every sphere is the bane of the present intervention. Be-
cause Secretary Taft, influenced by political exigencies at home, saw fit to treat
with the revolutionists of last August and to make certain agreements with
them, the present occupant of the executive palace is not free, as was General
Wood, to do whatever there may be to do with an eye single to the island's
welfare.
